awd_titl_txt: SMEFT, Collider, Neutrino, Axion, and Dark Matter Phenomenology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research of Professors James B. Dent, William Shepherd, and Joel W. Walker at Sam Houston State University.

Professors Dent, Shepherd, and Walker work to connect advances in theoretical physics to experimental results, with a focus on the properties of subatomic particles such as neutrinos and hypothetical particles called "axions".   They will also study the properties of the mysterious "dark matter" which provides 80% of the matter in the universe, and generally study the physics that emerges from large underground particle colliders. They will explore scenarios for new physics by developing new experimental search strategies, new data interpretations, new software tools, and new theoretical models.  As a result, this project will advance the national interest in fundamental science by exploring and connecting each of these research areas in particle physics.  Significant broader impacts will also be realized through the close supervision of undergraduate research students at Sam Houston State University, a primarily undergraduate institution that serves a diverse population.  The PIs will seek to guide students in developing their analytical, numerical, and creative skills through participation in journal publications and conference presentations, thereby creating a foundation for graduates to thrive in doctoral programs at major research universities.

More specifically, possible signatures of physics beyond the Standard Model at the Large Hadron Collider will be investigated through indirect effects encapsulated by the Standard Model Effective Field Theory, through the exploration of a new scale-invariant jet clustering algorithm, and through the development of public software tools that will facilitate such analyses. The PIs will also study coherent elastic neutrino-nucleus scattering, with an emphasis on the Mitchell Institute Neutrino Experiment at Reactor (MINER) collaboration. Dent and Walker are members of MINER and will continue to contribute to the simulation and analysis framework efforts, with the expectation of providing theoretical interpretation as data is generated.  Axion and axion-like particles will be investigated through possible interactions in the liquid noble and solid-state detectors used in dark matter and neutrino experiments (such as XENON, SuperCDMS, and MINER), including novel enhancements from optics-like Bragg and Borrmann mechanisms in crystal detectors. This includes the exploration of the feasibility of a new experimental program to search for axions and axion-like particles through photon disappearance experiments in solid state detectors. The dark matter studies within this project will focus on novel signatures for low mass dark matter including plasmon excitations and the neutrino background for such a signal, the Migdal effect with possible avenues toward its experimental calibration, and inelastic dark matter models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project have been the generation and dissemination of original published research, and the mentoring of undergraduate students in research at Sam Houston State University. The proposed work was an exploration of theoretical physics in the areas of SMEFT, collider,neutrino, axion, and dark matter phenomenology.

The PIs have delivered 13 published papers, two conference reports, six Snowmass white papers, and two pre-prints currently submitted for publication. This work has laid the foundation for a multitude of future lines of investigation for the PIs and their students, strengthened existing collaborations, and also aided in the development of new collaborative ties both within the PIs home institution as well as at other leading institutions.

The PIs presented their research at conferences and seminars, and multiple SHSU students were also afforded the opportunity to give presentations at international conferences.  The PIs also co-organized conferences and workshops including the annual Texas Astroparticle and Cosmology Symposium (TACOS), and the annual Mitchell Conference on Collider, Dark Matter, and Neutrino Physics.

The heart of the PIs' neutrino proposal has been work related to an examination of Standard Model (SM) and Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) physics through coherent elastic neutrino-nucleus scattering (CENNS), including spearheading the data analysis and numerical simulation support that is crucial to the Mitchell Institute Neutrino Experiment at Reactor (MINER) collaboration, which is developing a CENNS (and BSM) experimental program. This work will continue for years to come, and will continue to provide opportunities for undergraduate student researchers at SHSU.

On the collider front, the PIs have studied possible signatures of BSM physics at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), with particular attention to limits on the Standard Model Effective Field theory, dark sector phenomonology, difficult final states where new physics at the LHC can potentially hide, a new scale-invariant approach to jet clustering, and applications of Machine Learning to signal classification and signal versus background discrimination.  They have developed public software tools which facilitate such analyses.

Within the realm of axions and dark matter, the PIs have continued developments related to discerning the nature of possible dark matter and dark sectors through an exploration of a variety of models that can be tested with current and future experiments. This work has included proposing new theoretical and experimental probes of dark matter and BSM particles, including signatures at upcoming direct detection experiments, gravitational wave observatories, and gamma-ray observatories.

The proposed research incorporated the efforts of seventeen students and one recent graduate at SHSU, an institution that serves a wonderfully diverse and primarily undergraduate student population. The PIs have provided a research program that developed students' analytical, numerical, and creative skills, through participation in journal publications and conference presentations.  This effort has helped to create the foundation for students to thrive in doctoral programs at major research universities upon graduation from SHSU.  Three students involved in this project are now enrolled in graduate study, and several more have applications under review or are planning to apply upon graduation.  In addition, the PIs have worked toward the development of a new textbook based on their "Physics Bootcamp" course at SHSU, which introduces essential first and second year mathematics in a physics context. The textbook will be published by Cambridge University Press with a projected publication date of 2026.
